awd_titl_txt: Convergence Accelerator Phase 1 (RAISE): Fostering a Diverse Artificial Intelligence (AI) Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.  

The broader impact/potential benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project is to uncover key factors in engaging underrepresented high school students in Artificial Intelligence (AI) topics that lead to long-term pursuit of careers with an ultimate goal of increasing diversity in AI and better meeting the growing workforce demands. This project will employ an "AI First" model that emphasizes the concept of code that produces itself from data - a departure from traditional CS education that emphasizes coding alone.  Such a paradigm shift requires a multi-disciplinary approach. This proposal brings together experts in the field of Social Work, Computer Science, and STEM education outreach and leverages existing relationships between multiple universities and a nonprofit education organization. Through research studies that will uncover best practices in engaging students with AI and through complementary outreach efforts that will serve as test beds for research findings, this proposal will set the foundation for how to build a pipeline at the K-12 level to lead to a diverse and competitive AI workforce.  The end goal is that this diverse workforce will create new products using AI with less potential for bias.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase I project aims to address the lack of qualified and diverse candidate pool for the AI workforce sector.  It also addresses the growing concern that lack of representation among the AI workforce is resulting in creation of technology that is more likely to exacerbate societal biases, including sexism and racism.  The convergent research approach employed here involves: 1) refining primary research questions regarding K-12 engagement with AI curriculum and develop accompanying assessment tools to evaluate AI outreach programs; 2) identifying best practices in social work research to create a robust recruitment model that intentionally targets underrepresented groups in AI to education outreach opportunities; and 3) utilizing a social work framework to develop a model for a pilot internship program that connects students to employers and brings them further along in the pipeline to a career in AI.  This research will result in the development of a Toolkit that will be used widely by K-12 practitioners to engage more students and thereby create and even stronger pipeline of talent to enter the AI workforce in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Artificial intelligence (AI) is a field that has a large impact on society and the world, but is relatively new as a topic to be taught during high school. One major challenge in AI education is that AI brings together skills and concepts from multiple other disciplines. For example, students must learn how to code in order to complete their own AI project. In addition, AI algorithms are based on complex mathematics that are often not taught in high school courses. Systems thinking and an understanding of ethics and societal impact are also key concepts in AI education. Bringing these many skills and concepts together for students who have not had multiple years of post-secondary education offers a challenge, but is of vital importance given the current impact of AI on society. This project explores two aspects of curriculum and instruction: 1) how to design student-facing materials at a level that is rigorous, yet does not include unnecessary barriers for high school students, and 2) how to support instructors as they work with students in project-based learning environments. In addition, this project seeks to develop recruiting and admissions strategies that support the development of a diverse AI workforce, including using admissions practices that support students from groups historically excluded from AI. The project's impact on recruitment and curriculum and instruction are discussed further below.

Recruitment: 

As part of this project, we have developed diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) capacity building workshop materials. AI4ALL Summer Programs partner universities were able to  participate in these workshops and have access to a set of materials they are able to use with staff at their universities to continue building capacity in DEI practices. During this project, we have worked to develop a network of over 60 community-based organizations and schools that are able to support targeted recruitment because of their current and ongoing work with populations who have been historically excluded from the AI field. During this project, we identified the application process as a potential barrier for students to access AI4ALL Summer Programs. In response, we created the Outreach Ambassadors program; this program trains AI4ALL Summer Program alumni to serve as mentors to potential applicants and support them throughout the application process. During this project, we trained 15 Outreach Ambassadors to support potential applicants, with a particular geographic focus on the Midwest and Southern United States.

Curriculum & Instruction:

The curriculum aspects of this project began with scoping the concepts and skills necessary for students to complete an AI project. We entered into this work with the goal of ensuring the skills and concepts were at an appropriate level for high school students to avoid presenting additional barriers to students' understanding of AI. After updating our focus areas, we were able to reframe our curriculum around these skills and practices, while also taking into account project-based learning and systems thinking. Since many AI courses are often developed for advanced undergraduate students or graduate students, distilling AI down to a systems approach is not necessarily common in AI curriculum materials. In our materials, we use mathematics at an algebra level to reduce barriers to entry for high school students. For systems thinking, we focus on the inputs to an AI model (the data), the output of the model, and how to interpret that model. This shift to using a systems thinking approach allows students to develop their understanding of applied AI, while also providing some motivation for learning the deeper mathematical concepts in the future. 

AI4ALL Summer Programs are generally 2-3 weeks long, which does not offer a significant amount of time for students to become comfortable with coding. To address this, we developed a Python On-Ramping course that students have access to prior to their AI4ALL program. The purpose of this Python On-Ramping course is to help students build confidence in Python and to build the Python skills they need in order to be successful in an introductory AI project. These skills include understanding different data types and developing skills for manipulating data using Python (e.g., using the Pandas library in Python). 

Finally, we developed a series of instructor workshops to support instructors in using project-based learning pedagogy. These workshops included the following topics, among others: Leading student-centered discussions, using project-based learning pedagogy, and leading interactive coding sessions in virtual environments. 

The work done during this project relating to recruitment, curriculum, and instruction is now being implemented during the 2021 AI4ALL Summer Programs. After the Summer Programs are completed we plan to analyze the efficacy of our work in supporting students from groups historically excluded from AI.
